pricing_information.MRI: OKEU does not offer MRI scans nor St Jude's Hospital. There are 2 MRI machines: one at Tapion and one at La Clinic Du Corps. The price varies depending on the scan but it's between 600 to 2500 XCD.

acute_illnesses.name: Influenza (Flu)
acute_illnesses.description: A viral infection that affects the respiratory system, including the nose, throat, and lungs.

acute_illnesses.name: Appendicitis
acute_illnesses.description: Inflammation of the appendix, a small tube attached to the large intestine.
symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, usually starting near the navel and then moving to the lower right side
acute_illnesses.duration: Requires immediate medical attention; often treated with surgery.

acute_illnesses.name: Common Cold
acute_illnesses.description: A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, primarily caused by rhinoviruses.

acute_illnesses.name: Gastroenteritis (Stomach Flu)
acute_illnesses.description: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines, usually caused by viral, bacterial, or parasitic infections.

acute_illnesses.name: Strep Throat
acute_illnesses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Streptococcus bacteria, affecting the throat and tonsils.
symptoms: Red or white patches on the tonsils
acute_illnesses.duration: Usually treated with antibiotics; symptoms often improve within a few days.

acute_illnesses.name: Pneumonia
acute_illnesses.description: An infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid.
acute_illnesses.duration: Can range from a week to several weeks, depending on severity and treatment.

acute_illnesses.name: Migraine
acute_illnesses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe, throbbing pain, often on one side of the head.
acute_illnesses.duration: Typically lasts from a few hours to a few days.

acute_illnesses.name: Acute Bronchitis
acute_illnesses.description: Inflammation of the bronchial tubes, often following a cold or respiratory infection.
acute_illnesses.duration: Usually lasts a few days to a few weeks.

chronic_illnesses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
chronic_illnesses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels due to the body's inability to produce enough insulin (Type 1) or effectively use insulin (Type 2).
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in the hands or feet (more common in Type 2)

chronic_illnesses.name: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure)
chronic_illnesses.description: A condition where the force of the blood against the artery walls is consistently too high, which can lead to serious health issues like heart disease.
chronic_illnesses.duration: Lifelong condition if not properly managed.
symptoms: Severe cases may cause headaches, shortness of breath, or nosebleeds

chronic_illnesses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
chronic_illnesses.description: A group of lung diseases, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis, that cause airflow blockage and breathing problems.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially during physical activity

chronic_illnesses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
chronic_illnesses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the immune system mistakenly attacks the joints, leading to inflammation and joint damage.
chronic_illnesses.duration: Lifelong condition with periods of flare-ups and remission.
symptoms: Joint pain and stiffness, especially in the morning or after inactivity

chronic_illnesses.name: Asthma
chronic_illnesses.description: A chronic lung disease that inflames and narrows the airways, causing difficulty breathing.
chronic_illnesses.duration: Lifelong condition, often manageable with treatment.
symptoms: Coughing, particularly at night or early in the morning

chronic_illnesses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
chronic_illnesses.description: A gradual loss of kidney function over time, leading to the buildup of waste in the body.
chronic_illnesses.duration: Lifelong condition, which may progress to end-stage kidney disease requiring dialysis or a kidney transplant.
symptoms: Swelling in legs, ankles, or feet (edema)

chronic_illnesses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
chronic_illnesses.description: An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks the protective covering of nerves, leading to communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body.
chronic_illnesses.duration: Lifelong condition with varying degrees of severity and progression.
symptoms: Partial or complete loss of vision
Tingling or pain in parts of the body

chronic_illnesses.name: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
chronic_illnesses.description: A condition where the coronary arteries, which supply blood to the heart muscle, become narrowed or blocked, leading to heart disease.
chronic_illnesses.duration: Lifelong condition, often managed with medication and lifestyle changes.

chronic_illnesses.name: Parkinson’s Disease
chronic_illnesses.description: A neurodegenerative disorder that affects movement, leading to tremors, stiffness, and difficulty with balance and coordination.

chronic_illnesses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
chronic_illnesses.description: A chronic gastrointestinal disorder characterized by abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits without any visible signs of damage or disease in the digestive tract.
symptoms: Diarrhea, constipation, or alternating between both

subacute_illnesses.name: Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis (SBE)
subacute_illnesses.description: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and valves, usually caused by bacteria.
symptoms: Small red spots on the skin or under the nails (petechiae)
subacute_illnesses.additional_information: SBE develops more slowly than acute bacterial endocarditis, which is more severe and rapidly progressing.

subacute_illnesses.name: Subacute Thyroiditis
subacute_illnesses.description: Inflammation of the thyroid gland, often following a viral infection.
subacute_illnesses.duration: Usually lasts for weeks to months.
symptoms: Pain in the neck or throat
Initial hyperthyroid symptoms (nervousness, rapid heart rate) followed by hypothyroid symptoms (fatigue, weight gain)
subacute_illnesses.additional_information: Subacute thyroiditis often resolves on its own, but it can sometimes lead to temporary or permanent hypothyroidism.

subacute_illnesses.name: Subacute Combined Degeneration (SCD)
subacute_illnesses.description: A neurological condition resulting from vitamin B12 deficiency, affecting the spinal cord.
subacute_illnesses.duration: Develops over weeks to months if untreated.
symptoms: Weakness and numbness in the legs
Loss of position sense (knowing where your limbs are in space)
subacute_illnesses.additional_information: Early diagnosis and treatment with vitamin B12 can prevent progression and improve symptoms.

subacute_illnesses.name: Subacute Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus (SCLE)
subacute_illnesses.description: A form of lupus characterized by skin lesions that are more prolonged than those in acute lupus but not as chronic as discoid lupus.
subacute_illnesses.duration: Lesions can persist for weeks to months.
symptoms: Red, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas of the skin
subacute_illnesses.additional_information: SCLE often responds well to treatment with sun protection and topical or systemic medications.

subacute_illnesses.name: Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)
subacute_illnesses.description: A rare, progressive brain disorder caused by a persistent infection with the measles virus.
subacute_illnesses.duration: Develops gradually over months to years, but is considered subacute because of its initial prolonged course before becoming progressive.
symptoms: Motor dysfunction (e.g., muscle spasms, unsteady gait)
subacute_illnesses.additional_information: SSPE is fatal without treatment, but early intervention can slow the progression.

infectious_diseases.name: Influenza (Flu)
infectious_diseases.description: A viral infection caused by influenza viruses that primarily affects the respiratory system.
infectious_diseases.duration: Typically lasts 1-2 weeks, with most people recovering within a week, though fatigue may persist longer.
symptoms: Sometimes vomiting and diarrhea (more common in children)

infectious_diseases.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
infectious_diseases.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs, but it can also affect other parts of the body.
infectious_diseases.duration: If untreated, TB can last for months or even years. Treatment usually lasts 6-9 months with antibiotics.

infectious_diseases.name: HIV/AIDS
infectious_diseases.description: HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a virus that attacks the immune system, leading to AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) if not treated. HIV is a chronic condition.
infectious_diseases.duration: Lifelong, as the virus remains in the body. With antiretroviral therapy (ART), individuals can manage the condition and live long, healthy lives.
symptoms: Early HIV infection may cause flu-like symptoms

infectious_diseases.name: Malaria
infectious_diseases.description: A parasitic disease transmitted by the bite of infected Anopheles mosquitoes, caused by Plasmodium parasites.
infectious_diseases.duration: Without treatment, malaria can be fatal. With treatment, the disease can last from several days to a few weeks.

infectious_diseases.name: COVID-19
infectious_diseases.description: A viral infection caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which primarily affects the respiratory system but can have widespread effects on various organs.
infectious_diseases.duration: Symptoms can last from a few days to several weeks. Severe cases can lead to long-term effects known as 'Long COVID.'
symptoms: New loss of taste or smell

infectious_diseases.name: Strep Throat
infectious_diseases.description: A bacterial infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes that affects the throat and tonsils.
infectious_diseases.duration: With antibiotic treatment, strep throat usually resolves within 10 days. Without treatment, it may last longer and can lead to complications.
symptoms: Red and swollen tonsils (sometimes with white patches or streaks of pus)
Tiny red spots on the roof of the mouth
Swollen lymph nodes in the neck

infectious_diseases.name: Lyme Disease
infectious_diseases.description: A bacterial infection caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted by the bite of infected black-legged ticks.
infectious_diseases.duration: Early treatment with antibiotics can lead to recovery within weeks. If untreated, the disease can persist for months or even years.
symptoms: Early symptoms include fever, chills, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint aches, and a characteristic 'bull's-eye' skin rash.
Later stages can involve severe headaches, neck stiffness, arthritis with severe joint pain and swelling, facial palsy, and heart palpitations.

genetic_disorders.name: Sickle Cell Anemia
genetic_disorders.description: Sickle cell anemia is a hereditary blood disorder caused by a mutation in the hemoglobin gene. It leads to the production of abnormal hemoglobin (HbS), causing red blood cells to become rigid, sticky, and shaped like sickles or crescent moons.
symptoms: Episodes of severe pain (called sickle cell crises)

genetic_disorders.name: Thalassemia
genetic_disorders.description: Thalassemia is a group of inherited blood disorders that affect the body's ability to produce hemoglobin and red blood cells. In the Caribbean, beta-thalassemia is more common.
symptoms: Abdominal swelling due to an enlarged spleen or liver

genetic_disorders.name: Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) Deficiency
genetic_disorders.description: G6PD deficiency is a genetic enzyme deficiency that can lead to hemolytic anemia, particularly after exposure to certain foods, medications, or infections.
symptoms: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)

genetic_disorders.name: Cystic Fibrosis
genetic_disorders.description: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects the exocrine glands, leading to the production of thick, sticky mucus that can clog the lungs and obstruct the pancreas.
genetic_disorders.duration: Lifelong condition, but life expectancy can vary depending on management and complications.
symptoms: Digestive issues (e.g., greasy stools, difficulty absorbing nutrients)

genetic_disorders.name: Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome (BRCA1/BRCA2 Mutations)
genetic_disorders.description: Mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes significantly increase the risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers. This is seen in populations with specific ancestry links, including some Caribbean populations.
genetic_disorders.duration: The mutation is lifelong, but cancer may develop later in life.
symptoms: Multiple family members with breast or ovarian cancer
Presence of breast cancer in both breasts or multiple primary cancers in the same individual
Increased risk of male breast cancer, prostate cancer, and pancreatic cancer in family history

genetic_disorders.name: Hemophilia
genetic_disorders.description: Hemophilia is a rare genetic disorder where the blood doesn't clot properly due to the lack of specific clotting factors. Hemophilia A (Factor VIII deficiency) and Hemophilia B (Factor IX deficiency) are the most common forms.
symptoms: Excessive bleeding from cuts or injuries
Bleeding into joints, leading to pain and swelling
Prolonged bleeding after surgery or dental procedures
